importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the crash, when Brett James's plane crashed during a flight over Franklin, North Carolina, is critical to understanding the timeline of the incident and the investigation's focus.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe from the crash on September 18 to the preliminary NTSB report release on October 20 shows the duration of the investigation and public awareness of the incident.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter known for collaborations with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, while attempting a visual approach to runway 7 in Franklin, North Carolina.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the plane entered a 'tightening spiral' during flight, which led to the crash; no mechanical issues were found in the aircraft.

James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved by air traffic control, but failed to tune his radio to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), leading to loss of communication with controllers.

The pilot announced his position at 6,800 feet and intended to perform a 360-degree turn, but the controller attempted to reiterate that the radio frequency had not been changed, and there were no further communications.
The Cirrus SR22T aircraft flew over the runway and continued descending into a left turn before entering the spiral and crashing.
James's work with major music artists, including co-writing 'Out Last Night' for Kenny Chesney and 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood, made him a highly influential figure in country music.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James failed to switch to CTAF, which contributed to the loss of communication and situational awareness during the flight.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, 57, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, while attempting a visual approach to runway 7 in Franklin, North Carolina. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) determined that the plane, a Cirrus SR22T, entered a 'tightening spiral' due to a loss of communication with air traffic control after James failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), despite being instructed to do so. The incident occurred after James announced his position at 6,800 feet and planned a 360-degree turn, but the controller noted the radio frequency had not changed. There were no mechanical issues with the aircraft. James was a highly respected songwriter, known for co-writing hits such as 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood and 'Out Last Night' for Kenny Chesney, and had collaborations with major artists including Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, and Keith Urban, making his death a significant loss to the music industry.
title: Brett James' Plane Crashes in North Carolina After Radio Frequency Miscommunication
